input: Draft a treaty provision requiring states to establish a national authority responsible for implementing chemical weapons verification. The provision should specify the authority's main responsibilities and reporting obligations.
target: Each State Party shall designate or establish a National Authority to serve as the national focal point for effective liaison with the Organization and other States Parties. The National Authority shall be responsible for: (a) coordinating national implementation of this Convention; (b) receiving and responding to requests from the Technical Secretariat for information; (c) facilitating inspections conducted pursuant to this Convention; and (d) submitting annual declarations to the Organization.

input: Draft a treaty provision establishing a verification regime for monitoring compliance with limits on nuclear warhead stockpiles. Include provisions for on-site inspections and data exchanges.
target: Each State Party shall permit inspections by the Technical Secretariat to verify the accuracy of data declared pursuant to this Treaty. Such inspections shall include: (a) baseline inspections to confirm initial declarations; (b) periodic inspections not to exceed four per year at declared facilities; (c) challenge inspections upon request by any State Party with reasonable concern. States Parties shall exchange data on warhead stockpiles annually and notify the Organization of any changes within 30 days.

input: Draft a treaty provision requiring states to prevent the transfer of dual-use AI technologies that could be used in autonomous weapons systems. Include appropriate exceptions for peaceful purposes.
target: Each State Party undertakes not to transfer, directly or indirectly, AI technologies, components, or technical knowledge that could contribute to the development of autonomous weapons systems to any recipient unless: (a) the transfer is for exclusively peaceful purposes; (b) appropriate end-use assurances have been obtained; and (c) the recipient has committed to safeguards preventing military application. States Parties shall establish national export control mechanisms to implement this provision.

input: Draft a treaty provision establishing common but differentiated responsibilities for developed and developing countries in reducing greenhouse gas emissions, with specific numerical targets.
target: Developed country Parties shall reduce their aggregate greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40 percent below 1990 levels by 2030 and achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. Developing country Parties shall take nationally appropriate mitigation actions with the aim of achieving a deviation below business-as-usual emissions of 15-30 percent by 2030, contingent upon the provision of adequate financial and technological support from developed country Parties.

input: Draft a treaty provision requiring parties to establish protected marine areas and prohibit certain fishing practices that damage ecosystems.
target: Each Party shall designate marine protected areas covering at least 30 percent of waters under its jurisdiction by 2030. Within such areas, Parties shall prohibit: (a) bottom trawling; (b) the use of drift nets exceeding 2.5 kilometers in length; (c) fishing during spawning seasons as determined by the Scientific Committee; and (d) the harvesting of endangered species listed in Annex I. Parties shall establish monitoring systems to ensure compliance with these prohibitions.

input: Draft a treaty provision establishing a financial mechanism to support developing countries in climate adaptation, including governance structure and funding commitments.
target: A Climate Adaptation Fund is hereby established to provide financial resources to developing country Parties for adaptation activities. Developed country Parties shall collectively contribute no less than USD 100 billion annually to the Fund. The Fund shall be governed by a Board comprising equal representation from developed and developing country Parties and shall operate under the guidance of the Conference of the Parties. Priority shall be given to least developed countries and small island developing States.

input: Draft a treaty provision requiring states to ensure that tariff reductions are implemented gradually over a transition period, with special provisions for sensitive agricultural products.
target: Each Party shall reduce tariffs on goods originating in the territory of another Party in accordance with the schedule set forth in Annex A. Base rates shall be reduced in equal annual installments over a period of ten years. With respect to sensitive agricultural products listed in Annex B, Parties may extend the transition period to fifteen years and maintain tariff rate quotas during such period, provided that tariffs shall be eliminated entirely upon conclusion of the transition period.

input: Draft a treaty provision establishing a dispute settlement mechanism for trade agreements, including procedures for consultations, panel proceedings, and enforcement.
target: Any dispute arising under this Agreement shall first be subject to consultations between the Parties concerned for a period not exceeding 60 days. If consultations fail to resolve the dispute, either Party may request the establishment of a panel. The panel shall consist of three members selected from a roster of qualified experts maintained by the Secretariat. The panel shall issue its report within 90 days. Panel reports shall be binding unless rejected by consensus of the Parties. A Party that fails to implement a panel ruling within a reasonable period may be subject to suspension of concessions.

input: Draft a treaty provision protecting intellectual property rights while ensuring access to essential medicines for public health emergencies.
target: Each Party shall provide patent protection for pharmaceutical products for a term of at least 20 years from the filing date. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Parties may grant compulsory licenses for the manufacture and export of patented medicines to address public health emergencies, including epidemics of HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria, and other diseases. Such compulsory licenses shall be subject to adequate remuneration to the patent holder and shall be limited in scope and duration to the extent necessary to address the emergency.

input: Draft a treaty provision prohibiting torture and cruel treatment, with specific obligations for investigation and prosecution.
target: No person shall be subjected to torture or to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Each State Party shall ensure that all acts of torture are offences under its criminal law punishable by appropriate penalties. Each State Party shall undertake a prompt and impartial investigation wherever there is reasonable ground to believe that an act of torture has been committed. States Parties shall ensure that victims of torture have an enforceable right to fair and adequate compensation.

input: Draft a treaty provision ensuring the rights of persons with disabilities to participate in political and public life on an equal basis with others.
target: States Parties shall guarantee to persons with disabilities political rights and the opportunity to enjoy them on an equal basis with others. States Parties shall ensure that: (a) voting procedures, facilities and materials are accessible; (b) persons with disabilities may vote by secret ballot without intimidation; (c) persons with disabilities may stand for election and hold office at all levels of government; and (d) reasonable accommodations are provided to facilitate participation in political processes.

input: Draft a treaty provision establishing the right to privacy in the digital age, including protections against mass surveillance.
target: Every person has the right to privacy in their digital communications and data. States Parties shall ensure that any interference with this right is authorized by law, necessary for a legitimate aim, and proportionate. Mass surveillance programs that collect communications data of persons not suspected of wrongdoing are prohibited. States Parties shall establish independent oversight mechanisms to review surveillance activities and provide effective remedies for violations of digital privacy rights.

input: Draft a treaty provision requiring transparency and explainability for AI systems used in public decision-making.
target: When AI systems are used to make or support decisions affecting the rights or interests of individuals, the deploying authority shall ensure that: (a) affected persons are informed that an AI system is being used; (b) meaningful information about the logic involved is provided upon request; (c) affected persons have the right to obtain human review of the decision; and (d) the AI system and its outputs are documented in a manner enabling subsequent audit. This provision shall not apply where disclosure would compromise national security.

input: Draft a treaty provision establishing requirements for human oversight of autonomous AI systems in critical infrastructure.
target: States Parties shall ensure that AI systems deployed in critical infrastructure sectors, including energy, transportation, healthcare, and financial services, are subject to meaningful human oversight. Such oversight shall include: (a) human operators capable of understanding and intervening in AI operations; (b) mechanisms enabling human override of AI decisions; (c) regular human review of AI system performance; and (d) clear allocation of responsibility between human operators and AI systems.

input: Draft a treaty provision requiring risk assessments before deploying high-risk AI systems, with specific criteria for what constitutes high risk.
target: Before deploying an AI system, operators shall conduct a risk assessment to determine whether the system poses high risk to fundamental rights or safety. An AI system shall be deemed high-risk if it: (a) is used for biometric identification; (b) manages critical infrastructure; (c) determines access to education, employment, or essential services; (d) is used in law enforcement or administration of justice; or (e) influences democratic processes. High-risk AI systems shall be subject to conformity assessment, registration, and post-deployment monitoring.

input: Draft a treaty provision establishing an international body to coordinate AI safety standards and incident reporting.
target: An International AI Safety Authority is hereby established to promote safe and responsible AI development. The Authority shall: (a) develop and maintain international AI safety standards; (b) operate a mandatory incident reporting system for serious AI-related harms; (c) facilitate information sharing between States Parties on emerging AI risks; (d) conduct periodic reviews of AI governance frameworks; and (e) provide technical assistance to developing countries. The Authority shall be governed by a Council comprising representatives of all States Parties meeting annually.

input: Draft a treaty provision requiring states to criminalize the development and use of fully autonomous weapons systems.
target: Each State Party undertakes not to develop, produce, deploy, or use fully autonomous weapons systems, defined as weapons systems that can select and engage targets without meaningful human control. Each State Party shall adopt legislative measures to establish such development, production, deployment, or use as criminal offences under its national law. States Parties shall cooperate in the prosecution of persons accused of such offences and shall not grant asylum to persons fleeing prosecution for violations of this provision.

input: Draft a treaty provision requiring environmental impact assessments for projects that may have transboundary effects.
target: Each Party shall ensure that an environmental impact assessment is undertaken for any proposed activity listed in Annex I that is likely to cause significant adverse transboundary environmental impact. The assessment shall include: (a) a description of the proposed activity and its purpose; (b) a description of the environment likely to be affected; (c) an assessment of likely environmental impacts; (d) proposed mitigation measures; and (e) an outline of monitoring arrangements. Affected Parties shall be notified and given opportunity to participate in the assessment process.

input: Draft a treaty provision establishing labor standards in trade agreements, including mechanisms to address violations.
target: Each Party shall adopt and maintain laws and regulations providing for acceptable conditions of work with respect to minimum wages, hours of work, and occupational safety and health. Each Party shall effectively enforce its labor laws through appropriate governmental action. A Party shall not waive or derogate from its labor laws to encourage trade or investment. Where a Party's failure to comply with this provision affects trade between the Parties, the aggrieved Party may request consultations and, if unsuccessful, initiate dispute settlement proceedings.

input: Draft a treaty provision requiring states to protect the rights of refugees and prohibit refoulement.
target: No State Party shall expel or return a refugee to the frontiers of territories where their life or freedom would be threatened on account of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group, or political opinion. States Parties shall grant refugees lawfully present in their territory the right to engage in wage-earning employment, access to courts, and freedom of movement. States Parties shall cooperate with the Office of the High Commissioner in the exercise of its functions and facilitate its duty of supervising the application of this Convention.
